Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, watching my spouse stir their tea, the lines on their forehead deeper than usual. I knew I should ask what was wrong, listen, and share my own worries too—after all, we promised to be open with each other. But my mind kept drifting to the upcoming shutdown at work. Next week, every machine in the plant would be silent, and I was responsible for their maintenance and cleaning. It was the only window to get everything running perfectly again, and any mistake could mean costly delays. My supervisor had already reminded me twice how critical this was.

My spouse glanced up, catching my distracted look. “Is everything okay?” they asked softly. I wanted to reach out, to be present, but the weight of both roles pressed on me. I felt torn—my partner needed me to listen and share, but my thoughts were tangled with checklists and repair schedules. The silence stretched between us, heavy with unspoken words and the ticking clock counting down to next week’s shutdown.
